channel.title: Well...It's official
channel.description: This community can't really get anymore fucked up. 1st...Carney posts a trojan in the dl section. 2nd...Harley scams me for rs2 cash, fucking pixel hugger. 3rdly...I can't stress enough that these forums need to become more mature and learn more java.

item.title: Well...It's official
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

[quote=“aftereffect, post:1, topic:141226”]What do you expect from 10-12 year olds? They want every thing to come easy and handed to them with as little learning as possable.[/quote]Ahem… I’m 12 and I don’t want that =.= Infact, I was 11 when I joined. I was a bit noobish but look how I turned out.

Read full topic

item.title: Well...It's official
item.dc:creator: @swordskid61 Swordskid61
item.description:
@swordskid61 wrote:

[quote=“zoltanman, post:38, topic:141224”][quote author=swordskid61 link=topic=193455.msg1739223#msg1739223 date=1189241758]

lol im still earning java heres my first java applet (a calculator) =O

[code]//Fig. 3.13: AdditionApplet.java
//Adding two floating-point numbers.

//Java packages
import java.awt.Graphics; //import class graphics
import javax.swing.*; /import javax swing

public class AdditionApplet extends Japplet {
double sum; //sum of values entered by users

//intalize applet by obtaining values from user
public void init90
{
   String firstnumber;  //first string entered by user
   String secondnumber; //second string entered by user
   
   double number1;      //first number to add
   double number2;      //second number to add

   //obtain first number from user
   firstnumber = JOption.showInputDialog(
      "Enter fist floating point value");

   //obtain second number from user
   secondnumber = JOption.showInputDialog(
      "Enter second floating point value");

   //convert numbers from String to type double
   number1 = Double.parseDouble( first number);
   number2 = Double.parseDouble( second number);

   //add numbers
   sum = number1 + number2;

} //end method limit

//draw results in a rectangle on applets backround
public void paint( Graphics g )
{
//call auperclass version of method paint
super.paint( g );
//draw rectangle starting from (15, 10) that is 270
//pixels wide andd 20 pixels tall
g.Drawrect( 15, 10, 270, 20 );

   //draw results as a String at(25, 25)
   g.drawString( "The sum is " + sum 25, 25 );

}//end method paint

}//end class AdditionApplet[/code]
EDIT: theres still erors i have to fix and ima tweak! =O

Just by your signature, I know you didn’t make that.

i didnt say i did i said im going to tweak it to make it do multiplication geometry and graphs
[/quote]

How can you tweak it, when you can’t even type a command right? Look at the stupid code in your signature, the whole code is wrong.[/quote]
again like i said im a beginner OMG read … i dont consider myself any better then a ten year old but im studying.

Read full topic

[code]//Fig. 3.13: AdditionApplet.java
//Adding two floating-point numbers.

//Java packages
import java.awt.Graphics; //import class graphics
import javax.swing.*; /import javax swing

public class AdditionApplet extends Japplet {
double sum; //sum of values entered by users

//intalize applet by obtaining values from user
public void init90
{
   String firstnumber;  //first string entered by user
   String secondnumber; //second string entered by user
   
   double number1;      //first number to add
   double number2;      //second number to add

   //obtain first number from user
   firstnumber = JOption.showInputDialog(
      "Enter fist floating point value");

   //obtain second number from user
   secondnumber = JOption.showInputDialog(
      "Enter second floating point value");

   //convert numbers from String to type double
   number1 = Double.parseDouble( first number);
   number2 = Double.parseDouble( second number);

   //add numbers
   sum = number1 + number2;

} //end method limit

//draw results in a rectangle on applets backround
public void paint( Graphics g )
{
//call auperclass version of method paint
super.paint( g );
//draw rectangle starting from (15, 10) that is 270
//pixels wide andd 20 pixels tall
g.Drawrect( 15, 10, 270, 20 );

   //draw results as a String at(25, 25)
   g.drawString( "The sum is " + sum 25, 25 );

}//end method paint

}//end class AdditionApplet[/code]

[code]//Fig. 3.13: AdditionApplet.java
//Adding two floating-point numbers.

//Java packages
import java.awt.Graphics; //import class graphics
import javax.swing.*; /import javax swing

public class AdditionApplet extends Japplet {
double sum; //sum of values entered by users

//intalize applet by obtaining values from user
public void init90
{
   String firstnumber;  //first string entered by user

   double number1;      //first number to add

   //obtain first number from user

      "Enter fist floating point value");

      "Enter second floating point value");

   number2 = Double.parseDouble( second number);

} //end method limit

//draw results in a rectangle on applets backround
public void paint( Graphics g )
{
//call auperclass version of method paint
super.paint( g );
//draw rectangle starting from (15, 10) that is 270
//pixels wide andd 20 pixels tall
g.Drawrect( 15, 10, 270, 20 );

   //draw results as a String at(25, 25)

}//end method paint

}//end class AdditionApplet[/code]
